segment.source: Sideload Apps with DISM
segment.target: Sideload Apps with DISM

segment.source: Sideload Apps with DISM
segment.target: Sideload Apps with DISM

segment.source: Sideload Apps with DISM
segment.target: Sideload Apps with DISM

segment.source: You can sideload line-of-business (LOB) Windows apps to a Windows 10 by using PowerShell or Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM).
segment.target: You can sideload line-of-business (LOB) Windows apps to a Windows 10 by using PowerShell or Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM).

segment.source: Windows apps include:
segment.target: Windows apps include:

segment.source: Universal Windows apps devices: Windows apps built upon the Universal Windows app platform, targeting the universal device family.
segment.target: Universal Windows apps devices: Windows apps built upon the Universal Windows app platform, targeting the universal device family.

segment.source: Universal Windows 8 apps: Windows apps that target Windows 8.x.
segment.target: Universal Windows 8 apps: Windows apps that target Windows 8.x.

segment.source: Typically, Windows apps are available only through the Windows Store.
segment.target: Typically, Windows apps are available only through the Windows Store.

segment.source: You can submit LOB Windows apps to the Windows Store and make them available outside of your enterprise.
segment.target: You can submit LOB Windows apps to the Windows Store and make them available outside of your enterprise.

segment.source: However, you can also develop Windows apps for use only within your enterprise and add them to Windows devices you manage through a process we call sideloading.
segment.target: However, you can also develop Windows apps for use only within your enterprise and add them to Windows devices you manage through a process we call sideloading.

segment.source: Sideloaded apps do not have to be certified by or installed through the Windows Store.
segment.target: Sideloaded apps do not have to be certified by or installed through the Windows Store.

segment.source: Here’s what you’ll need to know in order to sideload apps:
segment.target: Here’s what you’ll need to know in order to sideload apps:

segment.source: How to?
segment.target: How to?

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Understand Sideloading Concepts
segment.target: Understand Sideloading Concepts

segment.source: Introduces some basic concepts you’ll need to know about sideloading apps.
segment.target: Introduces some basic concepts you’ll need to know about sideloading apps.

segment.source: Configure PCs for Sideloading Requirements
segment.target: Configure PCs for Sideloading Requirements

segment.source: Shows the requirements to be met in order to sideload apps on devices running different Windows Editions.
segment.target: Shows the requirements to be met in order to sideload apps on devices running different Windows Editions.

segment.source: Includes how to use Group Policy to configure your enterprise PCs for sideloading apps.
segment.target: Includes how to use Group Policy to configure your enterprise PCs for sideloading apps.

segment.source: Configure PCs for Developing Windows Store Apps
segment.target: Configure PCs for Developing Windows Store Apps

segment.source: Shows you how to configure your PC to have a developer license that does not expire.
segment.target: Shows you how to configure your PC to have a developer license that does not expire.

segment.source: The PC can be used to develop Windows Store apps or enterprise apps that will be added to your enterprise devices.
segment.target: The PC can be used to develop Windows Store apps or enterprise apps that will be added to your enterprise devices.

segment.source: Add Apps
segment.target: Add Apps

segment.source: Shows you how to sideload apps that you develop.
segment.target: Shows you how to sideload apps that you develop.

segment.source: Add Multiple Languages for Apps
segment.target: Add Multiple Languages for Apps

segment.source: Shows you how to prepare a multi-lingual image, sign-in to the image, install any desired app resource packs (including language) and then use Copy Profile to capture the image.
segment.target: Shows you how to prepare a multi-lingual image, sign-in to the image, install any desired app resource packs (including language) and then use Copy Profile to capture the image.

segment.source: Inventory Apps
segment.target: Inventory Apps

segment.source: Shows you how to list the LOB apps installed on the devices in your enterprise or in an offline Windows image.
segment.target: Shows you how to list the LOB apps installed on the devices in your enterprise or in an offline Windows image.

segment.source: Remove Apps
segment.target: Remove Apps

segment.source: Shows you how to remove individual instances of an app or remove the provisioning setting of an app.
segment.target: Shows you how to remove individual instances of an app or remove the provisioning setting of an app.

segment.source: Understand Sideloading Concepts
segment.target: Understand Sideloading Concepts

segment.source: Windows apps differ from Classic Windows applications in their design and in the way users can interact with them.
segment.target: Windows apps differ from Classic Windows applications in their design and in the way users can interact with them.

segment.source: To learn more about Windows apps , see what is a Windows Store App?.
segment.target: To learn more about Windows apps , see what is a Windows Store App?.

segment.source: You cannot sideload an app that has been downloaded from the Windows Store.
segment.target: You cannot sideload an app that has been downloaded from the Windows Store.

segment.source: To install Windows apps that are not part of your business line, you must use the Windows Store.
segment.target: To install Windows apps that are not part of your business line, you must use the Windows Store.

segment.source: To learn more, see Managing Client Access to the Windows Store.
segment.target: To learn more, see Managing Client Access to the Windows Store.

segment.source: LOB Windows apps that are not signed by the Windows Store can be sideloaded or added to a PC in the enterprise through scripts at runtime on a per-user basis.
segment.target: LOB Windows apps that are not signed by the Windows Store can be sideloaded or added to a PC in the enterprise through scripts at runtime on a per-user basis.

segment.source: They can also be provisioned in an image by the enterprise so that the app is registered to each new user profile that's created on the PC.
segment.target: They can also be provisioned in an image by the enterprise so that the app is registered to each new user profile that's created on the PC.

segment.source: The requirements to sideload the app per-user or in the image are the same, but the Windows PowerShell cmdlets you use to add, get, and remove the apps are different.
segment.target: The requirements to sideload the app per-user or in the image are the same, but the Windows PowerShell cmdlets you use to add, get, and remove the apps are different.

segment.source: This topic provides steps for both methods.
segment.target: This topic provides steps for both methods.

segment.source: Before you can sideload LOB Windows apps that are not signed by the Windows Store, you will need to configure the PC, see Configure PCs for Sideloading Requirements.
segment.target: Before you can sideload LOB Windows apps that are not signed by the Windows Store, you will need to configure the PC, see Configure PCs for Sideloading Requirements.

segment.source: When You’re Developing LOB Windows apps for Your Enterprise
segment.target: When You’re Developing LOB Windows apps for Your Enterprise

segment.source: LOB Windows apps that are not signed by the Windows Store must be cryptographically signed.
segment.target: LOB Windows apps that are not signed by the Windows Store must be cryptographically signed.

segment.source: The apps can only be installed on a computer that trusts the signing certificate.
segment.target: The apps can only be installed on a computer that trusts the signing certificate.

segment.source: For more information about how to sign an app and using certificates, see App Packaging Tools.
segment.target: For more information about how to sign an app and using certificates, see App Packaging Tools.

segment.source: However, you can use a developer license to add apps that are in development to your PC.
segment.target: However, you can use a developer license to add apps that are in development to your PC.

segment.source: For more information about testing apps that are in development, see Get a Developer License.
segment.target: For more information about testing apps that are in development, see Get a Developer License.

segment.source: You can use Group Policy to configure your domain-joined PCs to have a developer license that does not expire to support app development.
segment.target: You can use Group Policy to configure your domain-joined PCs to have a developer license that does not expire to support app development.

segment.source: Once the PCs are configured, you won’t need to connect to the Internet to obtain or renew a license.
segment.target: Once the PCs are configured, you won’t need to connect to the Internet to obtain or renew a license.

segment.source: See Configure PCs for Developing Windows Store Apps for more information.
segment.target: See Configure PCs for Developing Windows Store Apps for more information.

segment.source: Configure PCs for Sideloading Requirements
segment.target: Configure PCs for Sideloading Requirements

segment.source: Until the device meets all of the sideloading requirements, app tiles on the Start menu will show an "X" in the bottom-right corner to indicate that a problem is preventing the app from running.
segment.target: Until the device meets all of the sideloading requirements, app tiles on the Start menu will show an "X" in the bottom-right corner to indicate that a problem is preventing the app from running.

segment.source: In some cases, part of those requirements includes using a sideloading product key.
segment.target: In some cases, part of those requirements includes using a sideloading product key.

segment.source: This key provides use rights needed to deploy Windows 8, or Windows 8.1 apps directly to devices without having to install them through the public Windows Store.
segment.target: This key provides use rights needed to deploy Windows 8, or Windows 8.1 apps directly to devices without having to install them through the public Windows Store.

segment.source: Before you can add and run sideloaded LOB Windows apps that are not signed by the Windows Store you must configure your device based on the following conditions:
segment.target: Before you can add and run sideloaded LOB Windows apps that are not signed by the Windows Store you must configure your device based on the following conditions:

segment.source: For those devices that are joined to a workgroup, you must:
segment.target: For those devices that are joined to a workgroup, you must:

segment.source: Activate the sideloading product key on the device.
segment.target: Activate the sideloading product key on the device.

segment.source: And enable the Allow all trusted applications to install Group Policy setting.
segment.target: And enable the Allow all trusted applications to install Group Policy setting.

segment.source: See Use Group Policy to configure your enterprise PCs for sideloading apps.
segment.target: See Use Group Policy to configure your enterprise PCs for sideloading apps.

segment.source: This applies to:
segment.target: This applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10 Enterprise
segment.target: Windows 10 Enterprise

segment.source: Windows 8.1 Enterprise
segment.target: Windows 8.1 Enterprise

segment.source: Windows 8 Enterprise
segment.target: Windows 8 Enterprise

segment.source: Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry Enterprise
segment.target: Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry Enterprise

segment.source: Windows 8.1 Pro Update
segment.target: Windows 8.1 Pro Update

segment.source: For those devices that will be joined to an Active Directory domain, you must:
segment.target: For those devices that will be joined to an Active Directory domain, you must:

segment.source: Join the device to an Active Directory domain.
segment.target: Join the device to an Active Directory domain.

segment.source: And enable the Allow all trusted applications to install Group Policy setting.
segment.target: And enable the Allow all trusted applications to install Group Policy setting.

segment.source: See Use Group Policy to configure your enterprise PCs for sideloading apps.
segment.target: See Use Group Policy to configure your enterprise PCs for sideloading apps.

segment.source: This applies to:
segment.target: This applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10 Enterprise
segment.target: Windows 10 Enterprise

segment.source: Windows 8.1 Enterprise
segment.target: Windows 8.1 Enterprise

segment.source: Windows 8 Enterprise
segment.target: Windows 8 Enterprise

segment.source: Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry Enterprise
segment.target: Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry Enterprise

segment.source: Windows 8.1 Pro Update
segment.target: Windows 8.1 Pro Update

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: Windows Server 2012 R2 Update
segment.target: Windows Server 2012 R2 Update

segment.source: Windows Server 2012
segment.target: Windows Server 2012

segment.source: For those devices that will require a sideloading product key, whether the device is domain-joined or a member of a workgroup, you must:
segment.target: For those devices that will require a sideloading product key, whether the device is domain-joined or a member of a workgroup, you must:

segment.source: Activate the sideloading product key on the device.
segment.target: Activate the sideloading product key on the device.

segment.source: And enable the Allow all trusted applications to install Group Policy setting.
segment.target: And enable the Allow all trusted applications to install Group Policy setting.

segment.source: See Use Group Policy to configure your enterprise PCs for sideloading apps.
segment.target: See Use Group Policy to configure your enterprise PCs for sideloading apps.

segment.source: This applies to:
segment.target: This applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10 Pro
segment.target: Windows 10 Pro

segment.source: Windows RT 8.1
segment.target: Windows RT 8.1

segment.source: Windows 8.1 Pro
segment.target: Windows 8.1 Pro

segment.source: Windows RT
segment.target: Windows RT

segment.source: Windows 8 Pro
segment.target: Windows 8 Pro

segment.source: Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry Pro
segment.target: Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry Pro

segment.source: For certain Windows Embedded 8 Industry devices, you no longer need a sideloading product key whether the device is domain-joined or a member of a workgroup.
segment.target: For certain Windows Embedded 8 Industry devices, you no longer need a sideloading product key whether the device is domain-joined or a member of a workgroup.

segment.source: In this case, you must:
segment.target: In this case, you must:

segment.source: Enable the Allow all trusted applications to install Group Policy setting on the device.
segment.target: Enable the Allow all trusted applications to install Group Policy setting on the device.

segment.source: For more information about sideloading on Windows Embedded 8 Industry, see Enterprise guide to installing Universal Windows 8 apps on Windows Embedded 8 Industry.
segment.target: For more information about sideloading on Windows Embedded 8 Industry, see Enterprise guide to installing Universal Windows 8 apps on Windows Embedded 8 Industry.

segment.source: This applies to:
segment.target: This applies to:

segment.source: Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry Pro Update
segment.target: Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry Pro Update

segment.source: Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry Enterprise Update
segment.target: Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry Enterprise Update

segment.source: Use Group Policy to configure your enterprise PCs for sideloading apps
segment.target: Use Group Policy to configure your enterprise PCs for sideloading apps

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management Editor for a domain—based Group Policy Object (GPO) to which you will be applying the group policy setting, as specified below, to your selected PCs.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management Editor for a domain—based Group Policy Object (GPO) to which you will be applying the group policy setting, as specified below, to your selected PCs.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The steps provided in this procedure assume you understand the basics of Group Policy design and operations.
segment.target: The steps provided in this procedure assume you understand the basics of Group Policy design and operations.

segment.source: To administer domain—based Group Policy on a Windows 8.1 PC, you will need to install the Group Policy Management Console which is installed with the Remote Server Administration Tools for Windows 8.1.
segment.target: To administer domain—based Group Policy on a Windows 8.1 PC, you will need to install the Group Policy Management Console which is installed with the Remote Server Administration Tools for Windows 8.1.

segment.source: For more information about Group Policy, see Group Policy for Beginners and the Group Policy Techcenter.
segment.target: For more information about Group Policy, see Group Policy for Beginners and the Group Policy Techcenter.

segment.source: Click to expand Computer Configuration, Administrative Templates, Windows Components, and then App Package Deployment.
segment.target: Click to expand Computer Configuration, Administrative Templates, Windows Components, and then App Package Deployment.

segment.source: Double-click the Allow all trusted apps to install setting.
segment.target: Double-click the Allow all trusted apps to install setting.

segment.source: In the Allow all trusted apps to install window, click Enabled and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Allow all trusted apps to install window, click Enabled and then click OK.

segment.source: Setting the Group Policy to allow trusted applications updates the following registry setting: HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsAppxAllowAllTrustedApps = 1
segment.target: Setting the Group Policy to allow trusted applications updates the following registry setting: HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsAppxAllowAllTrustedApps = 1

segment.source: To activate a sideloading product key
segment.target: To activate a sideloading product key

segment.source: Open a command prompt with administrator privileges and type the following to add the sideloading product key:
segment.target: Open a command prompt with administrator privileges and type the following to add the sideloading product key:

segment.source: Where sideloading product key is the 25 digit key to enable sideloading on the computer.
segment.target: Where sideloading product key is the 25 digit key to enable sideloading on the computer.

segment.source: Activate the sideloading key by typing:
segment.target: Activate the sideloading key by typing:

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The activation GUID is not the same as the sideloading product key.
segment.target: The activation GUID is not the same as the sideloading product key.

segment.source: The activation GUID will always be ec67814b-30e6-4a50-bf7b-d55daf729d1e.
segment.target: The activation GUID will always be ec67814b-30e6-4a50-bf7b-d55daf729d1e.

segment.source: For more information about sideloading product keys, see the Windows 8 Licensing Guide.
segment.target: For more information about sideloading product keys, see the Windows 8 Licensing Guide.

segment.source: Configure PCs for Developing Windows apps
segment.target: Configure PCs for Developing Windows apps

segment.source: You can configure your PCs to have a developer license that does not expire.
segment.target: You can configure your PCs to have a developer license that does not expire.

segment.source: Once the PCs are configured, you won’t need to connect to the Internet to obtain or renew a license.
segment.target: Once the PCs are configured, you won’t need to connect to the Internet to obtain or renew a license.

segment.source: Your computer must be a member of a domain and be running either of the following operating systems:
segment.target: Your computer must be a member of a domain and be running either of the following operating systems:

segment.source: Windows 10 Enterprise
segment.target: Windows 10 Enterprise

segment.source: Windows 8.1 Enterprise
segment.target: Windows 8.1 Enterprise

segment.source: Windows 8 Pro
segment.target: Windows 8 Pro

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: To enable sideloading on Windows 8 Pro device, you must use a sideloading product activation key.
segment.target: To enable sideloading on Windows 8 Pro device, you must use a sideloading product activation key.

segment.source: For more information see, Configure PCs for Sideloading Requirements
segment.target: For more information see, Configure PCs for Sideloading Requirements

segment.source: To configure your enterprise PCs with a developer license
segment.target: To configure your enterprise PCs with a developer license

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management Editor for a domain—based Group Policy Object (GPO) to which you will be applying the group policy settings, as specified below, to your selected PCs.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management Editor for a domain—based Group Policy Object (GPO) to which you will be applying the group policy settings, as specified below, to your selected PCs.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The steps provided in this procedure assume you understand the basics of Group Policy design and operations.
segment.target: The steps provided in this procedure assume you understand the basics of Group Policy design and operations.

segment.source: To administer domain—based Group Policy on a Windows 8.1 PC, you will need to install the Group Policy Management Console which is installed with the Remote Server Administration Tools for Windows 8.1.
segment.target: To administer domain—based Group Policy on a Windows 8.1 PC, you will need to install the Group Policy Management Console which is installed with the Remote Server Administration Tools for Windows 8.1.

segment.source: For more information about Group Policy, see Group Policy for Beginners and the Group Policy Techcenter.
segment.target: For more information about Group Policy, see Group Policy for Beginners and the Group Policy Techcenter.

segment.source: Click to expand Computer Configuration, Administrative Templates, Windows Components, and then App Package Deployment.
segment.target: Click to expand Computer Configuration, Administrative Templates, Windows Components, and then App Package Deployment.

segment.source: Double-click the Allow development of Windows apps without installing a developer license setting.
segment.target: Double-click the Allow development of Windows apps without installing a developer license setting.

segment.source: In the Allow development of Windows apps without installing a developer license window, click Enabled and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Allow development of Windows apps without installing a developer license window, click Enabled and then click OK.

segment.source: Double-click the Allow all trusted apps to install setting.
segment.target: Double-click the Allow all trusted apps to install setting.

segment.source: In the Allow all trusted apps to install window, click Enabled and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Allow all trusted apps to install window, click Enabled and then click OK.

segment.source: Setting the Group Policy to allow development of Windows apps without installing a developer license updates the following registry setting: HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsAppxAllowDevelopmentWithoutDevLicense = 1
segment.target: Setting the Group Policy to allow development of Windows apps without installing a developer license updates the following registry setting: HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsAppxAllowDevelopmentWithoutDevLicense = 1

segment.source: Setting the Group Policy to allow trusted applications updates the following registry setting: HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsAppxAllowAllTrustedApps = 1
segment.target: Setting the Group Policy to allow trusted applications updates the following registry setting: HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsAppxAllowAllTrustedApps = 1

segment.source: Add Apps
segment.target: Add Apps

segment.source: There are two ways to add apps.
segment.target: There are two ways to add apps.

segment.source: A user can add an app package, which will make the app available to just that user.
segment.target: A user can add an app package, which will make the app available to just that user.

segment.source: Or the app can be installed in the Windows image, which will make the app available to every user of the Windows image at first logon or at the next logon, if the user account is already created.
segment.target: Or the app can be installed in the Windows image, which will make the app available to every user of the Windows image at first logon or at the next logon, if the user account is already created.

segment.source: This second case is referred to as provisioning an app package.
segment.target: This second case is referred to as provisioning an app package.

segment.source: Add an App Package
segment.target: Add an App Package

segment.source: You can install an app package (.appx or .appxbundle) on a per-user basis by using the add-appxpackage PowerShell cmdlet.
segment.target: You can install an app package (.appx or .appxbundle) on a per-user basis by using the add-appxpackage PowerShell cmdlet.

segment.source: There is no limit to the number of LOB apps you can add for each user.
segment.target: There is no limit to the number of LOB apps you can add for each user.

segment.source: Add a LOB app to a user account
segment.target: Add a LOB app to a user account

segment.source: At the Windows PowerShell prompt on a Windows 8 or Windows Server 2012 computer, add an .appx (or .appxbundle) file package.
segment.target: At the Windows PowerShell prompt on a Windows 8 or Windows Server 2012 computer, add an .appx (or .appxbundle) file package.

segment.source: Include any required dependency app packages when you add the app.
segment.target: Include any required dependency app packages when you add the app.

segment.source: For example, type:
segment.target: For example, type:

segment.source: For more information, see App Installation Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: For more information, see App Installation Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: Add a provisioned LOB app to a Windows image
segment.target: Add a provisioned LOB app to a Windows image

segment.source: Apps that are installed in the Windows image are called provisioned apps.
segment.target: Apps that are installed in the Windows image are called provisioned apps.

segment.source: Provisioned apps are staged in the image and are scheduled to be installed for every user of the Windows image at first logon or at the next logon, if the user account is already created.
segment.target: Provisioned apps are staged in the image and are scheduled to be installed for every user of the Windows image at first logon or at the next logon, if the user account is already created.

segment.source: You can add these apps to a Windows image when you boot into audit mode before you deploy the image by using the DISM app provisioning commands.
segment.target: You can add these apps to a Windows image when you boot into audit mode before you deploy the image by using the DISM app provisioning commands.

segment.source: For more information about audit mode, see Audit Mode Overview.
segment.target: For more information about audit mode, see Audit Mode Overview.

segment.source: Provisioned apps are specific to the PC and will not roam with the user.
segment.target: Provisioned apps are specific to the PC and will not roam with the user.

segment.source: You can only install 24 provisioned apps in an image.
segment.target: You can only install 24 provisioned apps in an image.

segment.source: On a Windows image that has already been deployed, you should instead use the Add-AppxPackage cmdlet in PowerShell.
segment.target: On a Windows image that has already been deployed, you should instead use the Add-AppxPackage cmdlet in PowerShell.

segment.source: If you do use the DISM app provisioning commands on a deployed Windows image with active users, you should log all users off of the image, so that you are the only user logged on, before you run the command.
segment.target: If you do use the DISM app provisioning commands on a deployed Windows image with active users, you should log all users off of the image, so that you are the only user logged on, before you run the command.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: On Windows 8, to update a provisioned app, you must first remove the provisioned app and then deploy the new version of the app.
segment.target: On Windows 8, to update a provisioned app, you must first remove the provisioned app and then deploy the new version of the app.

segment.source: The update will then be applied the next time each user logs in.
segment.target: The update will then be applied the next time each user logs in.

segment.source: On Windows 8.1 and newer, you no longer need to remove the provisioned app prior to deploying the new version of the provisioned app.
segment.target: On Windows 8.1 and newer, you no longer need to remove the provisioned app prior to deploying the new version of the provisioned app.

segment.source: Add a provisioned LOB app to a Windows image
segment.target: Add a provisioned LOB app to a Windows image

segment.source: Use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) command-line tool or PowerShell cmdlets to add the LOB app without a Windows Store license.
segment.target: Use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) command-line tool or PowerShell cmdlets to add the LOB app without a Windows Store license.

segment.source: For example, at an elevated command prompt, type:
segment.target: For example, at an elevated command prompt, type:

segment.source: Or, at a Windows PowerShell prompt, type:
segment.target: Or, at a Windows PowerShell prompt, type:

segment.source: For more information, see DISM App Package (.appx or .appxbundle) Servicing Command-Line Options or DISM Cmdlets.
segment.target: For more information, see DISM App Package (.appx or .appxbundle) Servicing Command-Line Options or DISM Cmdlets.

segment.source: For information about DISM supported platforms, see DISM Supported Platforms.
segment.target: For information about DISM supported platforms, see DISM Supported Platforms.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The computer does not have to be joined to a domain or have an activated sideloading product key before you install provisioned LOB apps.
segment.target: The computer does not have to be joined to a domain or have an activated sideloading product key before you install provisioned LOB apps.

segment.source: However, the apps will not run until the computer meets this sideloading requirement.
segment.target: However, the apps will not run until the computer meets this sideloading requirement.

segment.source: For more information, see Customize the Start Screen.
segment.target: For more information, see Customize the Start Screen.

segment.source: Update a provisioned LOB app once it is has been added to a Windows image
segment.target: Update a provisioned LOB app once it is has been added to a Windows image

segment.source: On Windows 8, to update a provisioned app, you must first remove the provisioned app and then deploy the new version of the app.
segment.target: On Windows 8, to update a provisioned app, you must first remove the provisioned app and then deploy the new version of the app.

segment.source: The update will then be applied the next time each user logs in.
segment.target: The update will then be applied the next time each user logs in.

segment.source: On Windows 8.1 and newer, to update a provisioned app, you will need to update the app for each user that has signed on to the Windows image provisioned with the app:
segment.target: On Windows 8.1 and newer, to update a provisioned app, you will need to update the app for each user that has signed on to the Windows image provisioned with the app:

segment.source: Update a provisioned LOB app to a Windows image
segment.target: Update a provisioned LOB app to a Windows image

segment.source: Use the PowerShell to update the LOB app without a Windows Store license.
segment.target: Use the PowerShell to update the LOB app without a Windows Store license.

segment.source: This must be done for each user that has signed in to the PC running the Windows image.
segment.target: This must be done for each user that has signed in to the PC running the Windows image.

segment.source: For example, if you have installed the original version of the app, 1.0.0.0, that now needs to be updated to version 1.0.0.1, then at a PowerShell session, type:
segment.target: For example, if you have installed the original version of the app, 1.0.0.0, that now needs to be updated to version 1.0.0.1, then at a PowerShell session, type:

segment.target: Once you have updated your app, you can verify the version of the updated app.

segment.source: Add Multiple Languages for Apps
segment.target: Add Multiple Languages for Apps

segment.source: To prepare a multi-lingual image, sign-in to the image, install any desired app resource packs (including language) and then use Copy Profile to capture the image.
segment.target: To prepare a multi-lingual image, sign-in to the image, install any desired app resource packs (including language) and then use Copy Profile to capture the image.

segment.source: Preparing a multi-lingual image for an app
segment.target: Preparing a multi-lingual image for an app

segment.source: Create an unattend.xml with the following contents to c:unattend.xml:
segment.target: Create an unattend.xml with the following contents to c:unattend.xml:

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: See Change the language used in apps for information about setting the language and installing updates from the Windows Store.
segment.target: See Change the language used in apps for information about setting the language and installing updates from the Windows Store.

segment.source: Sign-in to a local administrator user account from OOBE on clean image.
segment.target: Sign-in to a local administrator user account from OOBE on clean image.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: When adding a specific language to a Windows app, you would also want to Add Language Packs to Windows for the same languages as you did for the Windows app.
segment.target: When adding a specific language to a Windows app, you would also want to Add Language Packs to Windows for the same languages as you did for the Windows app.

segment.source: Add the desired languages to the current user’s language preference list.
segment.target: Add the desired languages to the current user’s language preference list.

segment.source: Install app updates using a Windows Store account (MSA account)
segment.target: Install app updates using a Windows Store account (MSA account)

segment.source: Sign-in to the store with an MSA account.
segment.target: Sign-in to the store with an MSA account.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Store only.
segment.target: Store only.

segment.source: Don’t convert the local account to MSA.
segment.target: Don’t convert the local account to MSA.

segment.source: If you do not have an MSA account, you can update apps without a Windows Store account.
segment.target: If you do not have an MSA account, you can update apps without a Windows Store account.

segment.source: Check for updates and install new language resource packs.
segment.target: Check for updates and install new language resource packs.

segment.source: Sign out of the Windows Store and remove the MSA account.
segment.target: Sign out of the Windows Store and remove the MSA account.

segment.source: Open an elevated command prompt and type:
segment.target: Open an elevated command prompt and type:

segment.source: Then press enter.
segment.target: Then press enter.

segment.source: You should see the PC boot to OOBE.
segment.target: You should see the PC boot to OOBE.

segment.source: Any languages that you have added prior to Copy Profile should be present at this point.
segment.target: Any languages that you have added prior to Copy Profile should be present at this point.

segment.source: Install app updates without using a Windows Store account (MSA account)
segment.target: Install app updates without using a Windows Store account (MSA account)

segment.source: After the PC has finished installing, open an elevated command prompt.
segment.target: After the PC has finished installing, open an elevated command prompt.

segment.source: Type Start ms-windows-store:Updates
segment.target: Type Start ms-windows-store:Updates

segment.source: You will see the Windows Store Updates page.
segment.target: You will see the Windows Store Updates page.

segment.source: You should see the pending updates displayed.
segment.target: You should see the pending updates displayed.

segment.source: Tap Install to install the updates.
segment.target: Tap Install to install the updates.

segment.source: Remove Apps
segment.target: Remove Apps

segment.source: You can remove individual instances of an app, or remove the provisioning setting of an app.
segment.target: You can remove individual instances of an app, or remove the provisioning setting of an app.

segment.target: Remove LOB apps per user account

segment.target: You can remove a single app for the current user only.

segment.source: Remove provisioned LOB apps in a Windows image
segment.target: Remove provisioned LOB apps in a Windows image

segment.source: When you remove a provisioned app, the app will not be installed for new user accounts.
segment.target: When you remove a provisioned app, the app will not be installed for new user accounts.

segment.source: For the currently logged in user and other user accounts that are active on the computer, the app will not be removed from those accounts.
segment.target: For the currently logged in user and other user accounts that are active on the computer, the app will not be removed from those accounts.

segment.source: The app will need to be uninstalled for those existing apps.
segment.target: The app will need to be uninstalled for those existing apps.
